awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Collaborative Research: Attaining the New Frontier of Spectral Efficiency with Tradeoffs in Computation Through Cloud Radio Access Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Cloud radio access networks (C-RANs) will be part of the next generation of wireless technology and will provide a leap forward in spectral efficiency. C-RANs promote a fundamental paradigm shift by employing a large number of simple base stations that consist only of radio heads (RRUs), while aggregating the baseband units (BBUs) of multiple base stations together at processing clouds connected through optical fiber or microwave links. This project will harness the potential offered by the centralization of the BBUs and the availability of a large number of distributed RRUs to attain scalable performance gains. This will foster the proliferation and improved penetration of wireless technology by supporting inexpensive, high-quality, ubiquitous energy-efficient spectrum access through emerging C-RAN technologies. The wider adoption of wireless technologies will allow traditionally under-served Americans to have better access to information services, thereby improving the nation's economic welfare. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in analytical and empirical research methods, which will improve the training of the nation's workforce. Collaboration will be fostered, and the results of the effort will be shared with the community through workshops focused on C-RAN technology. The research team will engage in activities to reduce the gender-gap in engineering by engaging local women in science and engineering clubs. 

The project develops a cross-layer approach to the design of scalable and efficient network strategies for C-RANs through a combination of mathematical techniques, exploration of context-specific tradeoffs, and innovative empirical strategies. The project seeks to 1) design optimal, information-theoretic codes and establish fundamental tradeoffs between coordination and communication rates for realistic scenarios; 2) design C-RAN scheduling techniques that cater to these optimal codes, as well as network dynamics, requested content, users' mobility, and radio conditions to provide scalable and efficient solutions for improved wireless communications; and (3) perform experimental prototyping of resulting communication and coding strategies on a C-RAN enabled wireless testbed to provide empirical performance validation and validate the underlying assumptions and models. The project is a holistic effort that will apply and contribute to the fields of information theory, queueing, and game theory as well as mathematical optimization, and empirical wireless research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cloud radio access networks (C-RANs) are among the most promising technologies to attain a leap forward in spectral efficiency by employing a large number of simple base stations (relays) and migrating all their processing units to a central processor in the cloud that is connected to the relays through optical fiber or microwave links. The centralization of the processing is not only cost efficient, but it also  allows for utilization of multiple relays for transmission to and reception from users to exploit diversity, joint information processing, coding, and design of transmission strategies across multiple relays  to share spectrum. This project  has undertaken a cross-layer investigation of the C-RAN technology with the goal of advancing the theory and design of C-RAN communication schemes using a merge of ideas from information theory, networking, and experimental validation.

 

Below, we summarize four outcomes of this project.

 

1) We have devised various coordinated communication strategies towards improving spectral efficiency by facilitating and exploiting cooperation among the users in C-RANs, multi-access channels, and broadcast channels using tools from information theory. Our latest accomplishment has been introducing a conferencing architecture that can be implemented at low cost,  and allows additional forms of cooperation among the relays and improves spectral efficiency in C-RANs. We have considered two models for CRANs: diamond broadcast and diamond multiaccess channels, devised novel coordinated coding strategies and established fundamental lower and upper bounds on the capacity of the network for each model. We have further established a duality result between the two models which would let translate results across models. 

 

2) Information theoretic designs, while near-optimal, are often computationally very costly and have long delays in performance.  One of the goals of this project has been to pave the path between information theoretic designs to practical strategies. We have done this for broadcast wireless channels with feedback, which are important components of C-RANs. We have developed scalable coding frameworks that seek spectral efficiency, under constraints on timely information transfer. Our strategies utilize useful coding actions but circumvent complexity of design by relying on scheduling frameworks. However, instead of different users/relays, different coding actions are scheduled for spectral efficiency. Our simulations demonstrate the success of this framework in scalability, improving timeliness of information transfer, as well as establishing tradeoffs between rate efficiency and timeliness.

 

3) Understanding applications of the C-RAN technology in V2X technology is another outcome of this project. We consider a novel CRAN framework which interfaces with the emerging V2X messaging technology. In this framework vehicles can collect signals and relay to CRAN base stations at traffic lights. The main challenge with this framework is that vehicular traffic flow changes with time, exhibiting sharp time-triggered transitions, due to external factors such as traffic lights. Thus, vehicular mobility process is temporally heterogeneous and not smooth. More specifically, traffic signals cause traffic synchronization, due to vehicles stopping during the red phase, and starting almost simultaneously during the green phase, which fundamentally alters the dynamics of CRAN signal relaying in a complex manner. As for wireless communication, communication heterogeneity will become an integral component of such a CRAN system - different types of vehicles may have different antennas with different communication capabilities. We propose a mathematical framework, based on a continuous-time Markov chain (CTMC), for characterizing the spatio-temporal spread of the CRAN signals (1) when the traffic flow exhibits sharp time-triggered transitions and (2) when there exists communication heterogeneity comprising of different antenna commutation capabilities and different wireless communication conditions. We prove that the state evolutions under the CTMC model converge to a set of differential equations in the asymptotic limit of a large number of vehicles, enabling computations that gracefully scale with increase in network size and the number of vehicles. Our framework can accommodate arbitrary traffic synchronization patterns corresponding for example to incorporate the presence of an arbitrary number of CRAN base stations. Furthermore, numerical computations using this mathematical framework answer several questions that influence the practice of CRAN network design and even security.

 

The results of this project have been submitted to/ published in information theory, networking, and wireless communication conferences and journals such as IEEE symp. Information Theory, Infocom, Transaction on Information Theory, IEEE/ACM Transaction on Networking, etc. Applications in transportation systems have been investigated and published in the journal of Transportation Research. Applications in public health have been investigated and published in the Royal Society Open Science journal.

 

The project has provided research opportunities for undergraduates and master students, and its findings have found their ways to graduate courses on networking, information theory, and wireless communications offered at University of Pennsylvania and Rutgers University.
